Literature Review: The evolution of carbon sources and sinks over the Phanerozoic eon has been a subject of intense scientific inquiry, with numerical modeling playing a crucial role in our understanding of this complex system. This literature review aims to synthesize the current state of knowledge regarding the modeling of carbon cycle dynamics throughout Earth's history, focusing on key events and processes that have shaped the planet's climate and biosphere.The Phanerozoic eon, spanning the last 540 million years, has witnessed significant fluctuations in atmospheric CO2 levels, climate, and biological activity. Numerical models have become increasingly sophisticated in their ability to simulate these long-term changes and provide insights into the underlying mechanisms driving carbon cycle dynamics.One of the fundamental processes in the long-term carbon cycle is silicate weathering, which acts as a negative feedback mechanism regulating atmospheric CO2 levels. Berner and Kothavala (2001) developed the GEOCARB III model, which incorporated this feedback along with other factors such as paleogeography and solar luminosity to reconstruct atmospheric CO2 levels throughout the Phanerozoic. Their results suggested that CO2 levels were generally higher in the past, particularly during the Mesozoic era, and have shown a long-term decline over the past 100 million years.Building upon this work, Royer et al. (2004) used an expanded version of the GEOCARB model to explore the sensitivity of CO2 predictions to various input parameters. Their study highlighted the importance of considering uncertainties in model inputs and emphasized the need for multiple proxy records to constrain model results.The role of biological evolution in shaping the carbon cycle has been increasingly recognized in recent years. Lenton et al. (2012) developed a model that incorporated the effects of land plant evolution on weathering rates and atmospheric CO2. Their results suggested that the rise of vascular plants in the Devonian period led to a significant drawdown of atmospheric CO2, potentially triggering the late Paleozoic ice age.Ocean biogeochemistry plays a crucial role in the carbon cycle, and models have been developed to simulate marine carbon dynamics over geological timescales. Ridgwell and Zeebe (2005) presented a model of ocean carbonate chemistry and sediment interactions, which provided insights into the long-term buffering capacity of the ocean and its response to perturbations in the carbon cycle.The coupling of carbon cycle models with climate models has allowed for more comprehensive simulations of Earth system dynamics. Donnadieu et al. (2006) used a coupled climate-carbon cycle model to investigate the impact of paleogeography on atmospheric CO2 levels during the Cretaceous period. Their results highlighted the complex interplay between continental configuration, ocean circulation, and the carbon cycle in determining global climate.Recent advances in modeling techniques have enabled the incorporation of spatial heterogeneity and regional processes into global carbon cycle simulations. Goddéris et al. (2014) developed a spatially resolved model of continental weathering that accounts for lithology, climate, and vegetation cover. This approach has provided new insights into the regional variability of carbon sinks and their response to global changes.The integration of increasingly complex ecological models with carbon cycle simulations has opened up new avenues for understanding the co-evolution of life and the Earth system. Bergman et al. (2004) presented a model that incorporated the effects of evolutionary innovations, such as the development of calcification in marine organisms, on the long-term carbon cycle. Their results suggested that biological evolution has played a significant role in modulating atmospheric CO2 levels throughout the Phanerozoic.While these models have greatly advanced our understanding of carbon cycle dynamics, it is important to recognize their limitations and uncertainties. Uncertainties in proxy data, incomplete understanding of certain processes, and computational constraints all contribute to model uncertainties. Addressing these challenges remains an active area of research in the field of Earth system modeling.Looking to the future, the development of more sophisticated models that incorporate a wider range of processes and feedbacks promises to provide even deeper insights into the evolution of carbon sources and sinks over the Phanerozoic. These models will be crucial for understanding past climate changes and for predicting the potential consequences of current anthropogenic perturbations to the carbon cycle.In conclusion, numerical models have played a pivotal role in advancing our understanding of carbon cycle dynamics throughout Earth's history. By integrating diverse datasets and simulating complex interactions between the atmosphere, oceans, biosphere, and lithosphere, these models have provided valuable insights into the long-term evolution of the Earth system. As we continue to refine and expand these models, we can expect to gain an even deeper understanding of the intricate relationships between carbon cycling, climate, and life on our planet.
